Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2016 09:37AM Luna52 wrote: Thanks for all the responses. Sounds like 4 weeks is a more realistic timeframe for starting to be more myself. Leading up to my BMX, I had a lumpectomy and then a re-excision. I felt good enough after a week or so to resume working from home. (I'm a data analyst so its not physical), After the BMX, not only am I sore but my brain is in a fog some of the time. Even if I had the energy to work, I wouldn't trust the results! amw, I too am a side sleeper and the compression bra is helping with that. Interesting that you are still sleeping in yours. xxyzed, I was only kept in the hospital overnight. Was there any special reason you were in for 8 days or is that just a difference in our medical systems? chemist, I would think another recent major surgery would slow down recovery. That's a lot of stress on your body. My husband attributes most of my brain fog to having had 3 surgeries with anesthesia over a few month period. One thing I am enjoying is my new flat chest. I was never especially fond of my breasts and I am having a great time surfing the net/sales for new shirts. Nothing like fall sales and free shipping ;-) Luna

The compression bra gives me some 'armor" - she was trashing around in her sleep the other night and gave me a small kick. That was a treat!

Posts.Content: Luna52 wrote: Hi All, Had my BMX on Sept 6, drains out 10 days later. All fine so far. But I am so darn tender on both sides. Is that just normal.. or maybe some fluid building up? I don't hear any sloshing.. Still have a compression bra which feels okay. I know everybody is different, but any general idea would help. How long did you rest up? When did you start things like grocery shopping or gardening? My friends want to drive me around (we live at the shore) .. which reminds me of my childhood with my parents saying "go outside and get some fresh air".. LOL But I mostly just feel like staying in the house and surfing the internet, watching Blue Bloods on Amazon and doing jigsaw puzzles. Should I be pushing myself more? Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2016 12:54AM Luna52 wrote: Michelle, I have tried a lot of Coobies. Coobies in the regular 'one size fit all', Coobies in medium size, Coobies in large, a couple of Coobies in their plus size. Coobies come with their own slight "padding" or you can slip your own form in the pocket. Also, one Fruit of the Loom sports bra. I've decided that my new size is 36 A and my best fit is high under the arm. What is your band & cup size? and where in your armpit is your best fit - high or low? I'll check my inventory and send you a free bra or two if you'd like. My "rejects" have only been worn once. I've been meaning to post here to pass some of them along. Only I could end up with twice as many bras post BMX than when I had boobs ;-) Luna

Posts.Title: Revision time! It's not quite flat enough. ravzari ravzari

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2016 04:34PM Luna52 wrote: I'm about 8 weeks post BMX. Some of the numbness in my chest is slowly resolving but I still have big patches where I can't feel anything. Especially just above my ribs and within the scar. It seems like it is always something in this recovery; recently my little dog ear has become more pronounced and gets irritated by every camisole, yoga top, bra I wear for more than a few hours. I'd go without anything but then it rubs against my shirt and also gets irritated. This too shall pass... and most likely be replaced by some new weird sensation LOL. EOT28: I guess I had pins and needles although I would have described them more as zingers in my chest. They seem to have abated for now. I had only one sentinal node removed and that was about 6 weeks prior to my mastectomy. Nonetheless, I developed cording in my right armpit. I'm about 3 weeks into PT and it is helping immensely. I'll be interested to hear what your physical therapist says. Great that she has experience with post-mastectomy therapy! notmyself: I am numb in one armpit. I don't particularly notice it unless I am showering or putting on deodorant. I assumed the feeling would come back at some point.. hmmm Luna
Posts.Title: Numbness after mastectomy and lymph node biopsy :( Momandwife36 lrwells50

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2016 07:19PM Luna52 wrote: Hi Joan, I can't answer your questions on reconstruction but I did have a double mastectomy this month. I had a lumpectomy first, followed by a re-excision, but there was DCIS in the margins both times. Had I still opted for radiation instead of more surgery, my risk would have been greater than I wanted. I was told that I can still get breast cancer even with my BMX. The reason is that individual breast tissue cells can be other places in your body. Mine was also HER2 but the tumor was too small to have much proven treatment value (chemo/herceptin) so I did not go that route. I am still waiting for the path report post-mastectomy but it is unlikely I will require radiation. Looking at your stats, your cancer was small, early stage and with clean margins and nodes. Your oncologist can best advise but from what I've learned, I don't believe you will see a statistical benefit for mastectomy. I met with a plastic surgeon but did not opt for reconstruction. My PC told me that a really good result requires dedication and time. I definitely lack the dedication, especially as it requires more surgeries. Age is just a number - my PC recently did reconstruction on a 77 year old woman. Best of luck with your research and decisions.. you'll learn a lot on this forum! Luna
Posts.Title: Need a forum for the choice of mastectomy JOANWILL55 Momine

Posts.Content: Luna52 wrote: When my surgeon calls it a simple mastectomy, I always think... "seriously?? you are removing both my breasts!" but I understand that is a medical classification. I've had a right breast lumpectomy plus sentinel node removal (for IDC) which was followed by a re-excision. Both times the margins contained diffuse DCIS. Also, mine is estrogen positive and HER2 positive but no treatment for the HER2 because the IDC was small enough that studies don't prove enough value given some of the possible complications at my age/health risks. I am now scheduled Tuesday for a bi-lateral mastectomy (my choice given the options and recurrence risk). No more nodes will be removed and I am not opting for reconstruction. Answering my post-surgery questions, my surgeon said I should be able to wash my hair at the sink and lift my arms to do some quick styling. ( I know, of all the things to be worried about, having my hair clean and fluffed should be the least of it. ) Does anyone have experience with "simple".. and does that make much of a difference in post-surgery mobility? I plan to train my husband or best friend this weekend if I can't groom myself ;-) Thanks in advance! Dx 7/1/2016, IDC, Right, <1cm, Stage IA, Grade 3, 0/1 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2+ (SPOT) Surgery 7/16/2016 Lumpectomy; Lymph node removal: Sentinel Surgery 9/6/2016 Mastectomy: Right; Prophylactic mastectomy: Left Hormonal Therapy 1/1/2017 Femara (letrozole) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: A little confused - recovery from "simple" bilateral mastectomy Luna52 Bluebirdgirl

Posts.Content: Luna52 wrote: I had a BMX with no reconstruction.. but has been hard getting to "ground zero" which is going flat around people I know via business. I've been away from my workplace for 3 months.. only working from home.. Colleagues insisted on a retirement party for me.. soo I showed up on Friday. I wore my mastectomy camisole with foobs..what a mistake! It felt like a heating pad on my chest. I started sweating and looked like a soggy rat after one hour. I went with a friend to the bathroom and "toweled off" ..it got better after that OK so that was embarrassing.. TODAY I went into the office for my final day (a rule in my company, you have to show up).. but damn it .. I went FLAT.. and it felt so much better. AND I didn't sweat.. Luna Dx 7/1/2016, IDC, Right, <1cm, Stage IA, Grade 3, 0/1 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2+ (SPOT) Surgery 7/16/2016 Lumpectomy; Lymph node removal: Sentinel Surgery 9/6/2016 Mastectomy: Right; Prophylactic mastectomy: Left Hormonal Therapy 1/1/2017 Femara (letrozole) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Flat Retirement! Luna52 ravzari

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2016 05:51PM Luna52 wrote: MTwoman says it well. The surgeon should go in for the lumpectomy and send the tissue for pathology report. Having had a lumpectomy, second excision to try for better margins and ultimately a mastectomy..I can tell you that the lumpectomy is very minor compared to UMX or BMX. It's all about the margins and your surgeon can't determine that.. mine was shocked that both the lumpectomy and second excision pathology resulted in DCIS too close to the margins. Best of luck, Luna

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2016 08:11AM Luna52 wrote: Hi Debiann, I am 5 weeks post BMX and have some side boob fat, which is a little uncomfortable. My BS says we need to wait some months before we'll know the final result. I can't tell tell what is swelling and what is permanent. I am overweight (5'4", 160 lbs) so I am not surprised to have some fatty tissue. It was there before my BMX so I didn't wear sleeveless shirts. My PS knew I wanted to be flat with no reconstruction, but she also did not want to take the incisions too far back and cause other problems. Overall I am happy with my results but will consider some touch-up, revision depending on how things settle down. Can you tell me more about your liposuction experience? How long was the healing time? Thanks, Luna
